title: Brutal injuries of shopkeeper who lost front teeth in 'petty' row over sign
text:

A shopkeeper had his front teeth knocked out and needs extensive dental treatment following an argument with his neighbour's son.

The argument was centred around an advertising board outside David Crews' deli, which his neighbour's son claimed was infringing on his mother's property.

David's wife Karen told Wales Online her husband was still in pain from injuries to his face - which required stitches to close up.

He had been told the dental treatment would take a year, she said.

“I've been in shock since it happened,” said David, 63.

(Image: Richard Swingler/Media Wales)

“I've been extremely shaky. I never expected to be assaulted outside my shop. I can’t believe it happened so quickly.”

The unprovoked assault happened on Friday, May 17 outside the couple’s deli on Pontcanna Street, which they have been running together since November 2016.

David was sweeping and arranging a display outside, while Karen was at the back of the shop, preparing for a wine tasting event.

Martin Warnett was clearing his mother’s home next door, preparing for her to move, and saw David move an A-shaped board advertising items like cheeses, wines and charcuterie.

He moved the board back and told David: “This is private property.”

(Image: Richard Swingler/Media Wales)

Speaking at Cardiff Crown Court , prosecutor Pamela Kaiga said David went over to talk to him, then: “Without warning, the defendant punched him to the face.”

Karen, 55, said she was working in the back of the shop when the incident happened, adding: “There he was, standing on the step – all bloody.”

The incident was caught on CCTV and Karen said she saw her husband spitting his teeth out onto the floor.

David went to A&E at the University Hospital of Wales and was treated for the injuries to his mouth, as well as cuts to his nose and lips.

Karen said her husband’s two front teeth were knocked out by the punch and he has already had five or six trips to the dentist.

The dental treatment has cost more than £6,000 so far and is expected to take another year.

(Image: Media Wales)

She explained her husband’s teeth were “smashed” and he will have to have dental implants, adding: “He is still in a lot of pain.”

Karen, who is having tests to be a kidney donor, said David has stage five renal failure and had to delay his treatment while having dental surgery.

In a statement read out in court, David said he liked to keep the area outside the shop clean and tidy and could not believe he had been punched because of a dispute about the board.

Following the assault, Warnett went into another shop and admitted he had just hit someone. That shopkeeper noticed a cut on his hand and thought he looked “edgy”.

Police officers found the defendant at Sophia Gardens and he told them: “I hit him. I punched him once to the face.”

Warnett claimed: “He came out shouting and swearing with a broom. I feared I was going to get hurt."

(Image: Richard Swingler/Media Wales)

The defendant told the police he had a previous caution for assault and had tried to stay “out of trouble”, but believed the shopkeeper was going to hit him with the broom.

Prosecutors said he did not have any previous convictions, but he was cautioned in November 2015 for common assault in Cathays .

Ms Kaiga told the court: “He had an issue with where the victim had parked her car. He shouted at her and proceeded to kick her car then slapped her in the face.”

Warnett, 47, from Nant y Wedal in Cathays, admitted inflicting grievous bodily harm.

(Image: Richard Swingler/Media Wales)

Gareth Morley, defending, said his client had kept out of trouble since his caution four years ago. He pointed out this incident involved a single punch and no weapon was used.

He accepted the dispute about the A-board was “a very trivial matter” and “absolutely petty”.

Mr Morley said Warnett is not working and has to pay a mortgage, as well as supporting his wife and children, while living on savings.

Judge Eleri Rees replied: “He is going to have to pay compensation.”

She noted the assault happened “completely out of the blue” and caused injuries that were “unpleasant and distressing”.

The judge added: “It seems to me it was completely unprovoked and out of proportion to what should have been a minor irritation.

(Image: Richard Swingler/Media Wales)

“This was a petty dispute which should never have resulted in violence. You have an issue with your temper, it seems to me, at times.”

Warnett was given a 12-month community order, requiring him to complete 120 hours of unpaid work and 20 days of a rehabilitation activity.

He will have to pay £8,000 in compensation, plus an £85 victim surcharge within the next year. A two-year restraining order was imposed.

Speaking after the hearing, Karen said she thought it was important the defendant should pay for the dental work.

She said she thought it was a “light sentence” and there may be nothing left of the compensation once the dentist bills have been paid.
description: WARNING - DISTRESSING FOOTAGE: A Cardiff shopkeeper had his front teeth knocked out in a brawl with his neighbour's son, following a dispute over who's property an advertising board sat on
